I got rejected by Cashfree because I failed to answer a hard-level DP follow up.

All 30+ LPA roles so the rejection hurt quite a LOT.

But I learned one thing → DSA is everywhere!

 Mid-Level roles? DSA makes or breaks your application.
 Senior Level roles? DSA is still your entry ticket to more advanced rounds.

 I stopped ‘solving’ DSA problems on LeetCode and started breaking them down into patterns I could reuse.
 I revised core CS subjects (OS, CN, DBMS, OOP) with the same seriousness as DSA.
 I began doing mock interviews with senior SDEs and peers, because they can spot your blind spots better than you can yourself.

I lost an offer from D.E. Shaw because of ONE binary tree question…

Yep, just one DSA follow-up, and it cost me a 30+ LPA opportunity. 😔

Here’s my full interview experience at D.E. Shaw so you know what to prepare for 👇

💠 Round 1: Online Assessment (90 mins)

→ 1 DP question [medium-hard]
→ 1 array-based problem [easy-medium]
→ 60 MCQs across core CS fundamentals and debugging

💠 Round 2: CodePair Round (Interview)

→ 0-1 Knapsack variant (solved ✅)
→ Binary Tree + tricky follow-up (fumbled here ❌)
→ 1 logical puzzle

I had a strong first round and was doing fairly well in the second, until the binary tree question turned into a follow-up I hadn’t anticipated.

And that one gap in handling edge cases ended my run.

Here’s what I learned → 

In interviews with top PBCs, it’s not just about solving the question. It’s about handling follow-ups, edge cases, and communicating clearly. You can get 80% of the logic right and still not clear the round.

And this rejection pushed me to go deeper into DSA, not just solving, but building pattern recognition, optimizing my approach, and improving how I explain.

In my early days, I got rejected by every single company I applied to 😞💔
All because of this one simple mistake:

🔴 Jumping straight into code.
I’d miss edge cases, pick the wrong approach…
Here’s the framework that finally helped me crack coding interviews:

📌 Minute 1-2: Clarify the problem
Ask for edge cases, input/output expectations, constraints.
📌 Minute 3-5: Walk through examples
Pick a small input and dry-run it. Think out loud. Build trust.
📌 Minute 6-8: Talk brute force
Even if it’s not optimal, start somewhere. Thinking matters more than the final answer.
📌 Minute 9-10: Ask: “Can I start coding?”
Let the interviewer know your plan. Be collaborative, not silent.

Now, just knowing this framework isn’t enough. You need to practice it regularly to structure your thoughts and stay calm during the follow-ups. Mock interviews helped me develop that skill. ✔️

If I had to start DSA from scratch in 2025, here’s the exact roadmap I’d follow:

💡Start with any Language - C++, Java, or Python — doesn't matter. Learn basics and start solving.

📅 Week 1–2: Arrays & Strings
Sliding Window, Two Pointers, Prefix Sum, Binary Search on Arrays, Sorting, Greedy Techniques

📅 Week 2–3: Linked Lists
Fast & Slow Pointers, Pointer Manipulation, Dummy Nodes, Cycle Detection (Floyd’s), In-place Reversal

📅 Week 3: Stacks & Queues
Monotonic Stack/Queue, Infix → Postfix Conversion, Stack Simulation, LRU Logic, Circular Queue Techniques

📅 Week 4: Heaps & Priority Queues
Min/Max Heaps, Heapify Logic, Custom Comparators, Greedy with Heaps, Multi-way Merge

📅 Week 5–6: Trees & Graphs
Trees: DFS, BFS Traversals, Recursion on Trees, Lowest Common Ancestor, Depth, Height, Diameter, Binary Search Tree (BST) Ops
Graphs: Adjacency List/Matrix, DFS, BFS, Topological Sort, Union-Find (DSU), Dijkstra, Prim (Basics)

📅 Week 7: Recursion & Backtracking
Subset Generation, Permutations & Combinations, Maze & Grid Pathfinding, Decision Trees, State Tracking & Restoration

📅 Week 8: Dynamic Programming
Memoization & Tabulation, 1D, 2D, and Space Optimized DP, State Transition Formulas, DP with Choices, DP on Subsequences, Grids, Trees

📅 Week 9: Tries & Advanced Strings
Trie Construction, Prefix Matching, Pattern Searching (KMP, Z Algo), String Hashing, Suffix Arrays & Bit Tricks (optional)

🎯 Afterwards:
Pick a DSA Sheet (Striver, NeetCode, Babbar), Solve 1–2 problems daily, Participate in weekly contests
It starts with a dream, grows with belief, and ends in achievement. 🌟

The Resume tips I followed to Get Shortlisted at all - Amazon, Flipkart, D.E. Shaw & Arcesium… 🚀

If you're applying to top PBCs and your resume isn’t even making it to the interviews…

Let’s fix that first. 💥

Here’s the exact resume checklist that helped me get into interviews at companies like Amazon, Flipkart, Sprinklr, Arcesium, and more 👇

1️⃣ Tailor it to the Job Description
Don’t use one generic resume. Highlight relevant skills for each role.

2️⃣ Use action-oriented language
Words like Built, Designed, Reduced show initiative and ownership.

3️⃣ Show impact
Focus on outcomes, not just responsibilities. → "Reduced query time by 40%" > "Worked on database."

4️⃣ Quantify wherever possible
Numbers help you stand out immediately.

5️⃣ Keep it clean & short
For most, one page is enough. Especially if you're somewhere between 1-5 YOE.

6️⃣ Make your work clickable
Add GitHub links, live project demos, portfolio, make your work speak.

7️⃣ Don’t forget this:
Include contact info, LinkedIn, LeetCode/GitHub/Coding links in the header. Make it easy for recruiters.

These steps made all the difference for me.

But if you're still not landing interviews, it might be time to get your resume reviewed by someone who's cracked these companies.
